The development of efficient catalysts for the stepwise oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to 2,5-diformyl furan (DFF), 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA), 5-Formyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (FFCA) or 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) is critical for biomass valorization. Herein, we reported a bimetallic Co-Mn catalyst anchored on nitrogen-doped porous carbon, which was used for the oxidation of HMF to FDCA, avoiding the use of high temperature and high-pressure oxygen. High FDCA selectivity (>95 %) was achieved through reaction condition optimization. And HMF→DFF→FFCA→FDCA was considered to be the main reaction pathway during the whole oxidation process. Additionally, the chemical environment of the constituent elements of the used catalyst was analyzed by XPS. TEM revealed that the catalyst retained its porous structure and excellent metal dispersion after the reaction. This structural stability was corroborated by sustained >90 % FDCA selectivity over five consecutive reaction cycles. This work established a dual-metal synergy strategy for multi-step oxidation pathways, offering insights into the design of robust catalysts for biomass-derived platform molecule upgrading. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Oxidation 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid Bimetallic cobalt and manganese catalyst Tert-butyl hydroperoxide Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction The green and sustainable development of renewable resources is pivotal in addressing the pressing environmental issues and resource scarcity that our planet currently faces. In this context, lignocellulosic biomass, primarily composed of cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin, emerges as a significant renewable resource [1,2]. The comprehensive utilization of lignocellulosic materials presents an encouraging prospect for achieving decarbonization goals within energy and chemical supply chains, thereby facilitating the early realization of net-zero carbon emissions [3]. Through the catalytic conversion of lignocellulosic resources, a myriad of high-value chemicals can be synthesized, including acetic acid, furfural, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), vanillin, and ferulic acid, among others [4,5]. Notably, HMF is considered a key platform compound. Its catalytic transformation can yield vital bio-based monomers such as diformylfuran (DFF) and furan dicarboxylic acid (FDCA) [6–8]. These bio-based monomers are poised to replace molecules derived from fossil fuels, advancing the cause of carbon neutrality. Specifically, FDCA is viewed as a substitute for petroleum-derived terephthalic acid (TPA), used in the production of polyethylene furanoate (PEF), a type of bioplastic. The PEF derived from FDCA holds significant promise to replace PET materials and play a pivotal role in applications spanning food packaging, electronics, automotive, and textile industries [9–12]. This makes it a promising alternative to PET in applications spanning food packaging, electronics, automotive, and textile industries. By 2025, the market value of FDCA is projected to reach around 770 million euros, with an annual compound growth rate of about 11 % [13]. Consequently, research into efficient and eco-friendly synthesis techniques for converting HMF into FDCA is both crucial and urgent. In recent years, significant advancements in catalytic strategies have been developed to enhance the efficient utilization of HMF for the selective synthesis of FDCA [14–16]. The conversion of HMF to FDCA involves sequential oxidation of both hydroxyl and aldehyde functional groups [17], accompanied by the generation of multiple reactive intermediates. This process necessitates precise regulation of active sites on catalyst surfaces, including oxygen vacancies, acid-base properties, and activated oxygen species derived from oxidants. Despite progress, achieving high efficiency and selectivity in FDCA synthesis remains challenging. Noble metal-based catalysts (e.g., Au, Pd, Pt, Ru) have demonstrated notable catalytic performance in HMF oxidation [17–26]. However, their high cost and limited scalability hinder commercial applications in biomass valorization [27]. Consequently, the development of cost-effective non-noble metal catalysts has emerged as a critical research focus. Transition metal oxides, such as MnCo2O4, have been explored for FDCA production, achieving a 71 % yield under 1 MPa O2 (Zhang et al.) [28]. Similarly, LiNixMnγCo2O2 catalysts reported by Amarasekara et al. delivered FDCA yields of 82–97 % at 120–140 °C [29]. These studies highlighted the requirement for elevated oxygen pressures to enhance solvent oxygen solubility and reaction efficiency. Alternative oxidants, including H2O2, AcOOH, and t-BuOOH, were also investigated. For instance, Co-Cu/AC catalysts coupled with H2O2 and Na2CO3 achieved 99 % HMF conversion and 92 % FDCA yield at 170 °C over 9 h (Chanatip Samart et al.) [30]. The Baeyer-Villiger oxidation mechanism predominated when AcOOH was employed for aldehyde-to-carboxyl conversion [31]. Moreover, t-BuOOH was also a highly effective oxidant that has been frequently investigated in recent years. Wang et al. developed an Fe3O4 CoOx system in DMSO, yielding 68 % FDCA at 80 °C over 720 min [32]. Notably, non-noble Cu-Mn oxides achieved 96 % FDCA yield under t-BuOOH-mediated conditions [33]. Fe-grafted MOF catalysts (Richard I. Walton et al.) exhibited high activity (TOF > 800 h⁻¹), attaining full HMF conversion and 70–80 % FDCA yield [34]. Furthermore, S- and P-doped CoFeS and CoFeP-400 catalysts (Gao et al.) achieved >87 % FDCA yields under optimized conditions [35]. Prasad et al. demonstrated that Ni-Co oxide catalysts with tunable Co/Ni ratios enhanced oxidative activity [36]. These studies underscored the critical role of multi-metal synergism in improving catalytic performance, attributed to enhanced redox properties, acid-base tunability, and high oxygen mobility facilitated by 3d orbital interactions [37,38]. Nevertheless, challenges persisted in the stability of metal oxide catalysts under acidic and corrosive reaction environments. Future efforts could prioritize the design of robust, non-noble heterogeneous catalysts to advance scalable FDCA production. In this manuscript, a bimetallic CoMn-NC catalytic system used for the catalytic oxidation of HMF to FDCA was developed, and t-BuOOH was used as the oxidant. A series of catalysts were synthesized to leverage the synergistic redox interplay between Co and Mn species, optimizing both activity and stability. Systematic investigations were conducted to elucidate the effects of reaction parameters (temperature, solvent, oxidant loading) on catalytic performance, complemented by advanced characterization techniques (XPS, TEM, XRD, BET) to probe structural and electronic properties. Time-resolved profiling and intermediate tracking were employed to validate the stepwise oxidation pathway. Comprehensive post-reaction characterization via XPS and TEM provided critical insights into the catalyst's stability and active-site evolution. Experimental section Materials and reagents All chemical reagents and solvents were procured from commercial suppliers, including Alfa Aesar, Sigma, Adamas - beta, Energy Chemical, TCI, and Aladdin. These materials were directly utilized in the experiments without undergoing any additional purification steps. Preparation of the catalyst The synthesis method of the catalyst described in the manuscript was refered to previous work [39]. Briefly, 2.5 mmol CoCl2, 2.5 mmol MnCl2, and 2 g of 1,10-phenanthroline were added to 200 mL of ethanol. The resulting mixture was stirred at 60 °C for 30 min. Subsequently, 20 g Mg(OH)2 was added and stirring continued for 120 min. After the reaction was completed, the mixture was cooled to room temperature and ethanol was removed via vacuum distillation. The resulting solid mixture was dried overnight in a vacuum oven at 60 °C and ground into powder. The powder was calcined in a tubular furnace under N2 atmosphere at 700 °C for 2 h (heating rate of 5 °C/min). The obtained black powder was then stirred in a 4 M HNO3 solution at room temperature for 12 h. After filtration and drying, the obtained catalyst was named CoMn-NC. The synthesis methods of Fe-NC, Co-NC, Ni-NC, and Mn-NC were the similar as above. Typical experimental procedures for synthesis of FDCA from HMF To a 10 mL reaction tube equipped with a stir bar, 0.1 mmol HMF and 10 mg catalyst were added to the reaction tube. Then, 1 mL of acetonitrile was introduced as the solvent and 1 mmol t-BuOOH (70 % aqueous solution, calculated in t-BuOOH quantity) was also added. The reaction mixture was stirred for 12 h at 80 °C. Quantitative analysis of HMF, DFF, FFCA and FDCA was performed via HPLC with a C18 column at 30 °C. The mobile phase used by HPLC was MeOH (20 %) and H2O (80 %, containing 0.5 % CF3COOH). The conversion of the substrate and products yield were calculated as follows: Conversion ( % ) = ( 1 − n n 0 ) × 100 % Yield ( % ) = n p n 0 × 100 % Carbon Yield ( % ) = n c n 0 × 100 % where n0 meant the initial mole of the substrate before the reaction; n and np meant the moles of the substrate and products after the reaction; nc meant the total moles of DFF, FFCA and FDCA. Catalyst recycling After the reaction, the mixture was cooled to room temperature and centrifuged at 10,000 rpm for 5 min to separate the solid catalyst from the liquid phase. The recovered catalyst was washed thoroughly with acetonitrile to remove residual reactants and organic byproducts, followed by centrifugation after each washing cycle. The washed catalyst was then dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 6 h to eliminate residual solvent. The dried CoMn-NC catalyst was directly reused in subsequent catalytic cycles without further treatment. Catalysts characterization The physicochemical properties of the synthesized catalysts were systematically investigated using a combination of advanced characterization techniques. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis was performed on a field-emission SEM instrument (ZEISS Sigma 300) to examine the surface morphology and particle size distribution. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were acquired using the FEI Talos F200X G2 microscope. Additionally, energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy mapping (EDX-Mapping) coupled with the TEM was employed to confirm the homogeneous distribution of elements across the catalyst surface. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained by theta rotating anode X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku SmartLab SE) with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) in the 2θ range of 10°−80° at a scanning rate of 2° min⁻¹. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were conducted on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer using a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source (1486.6 eV), and all binding energies were calibrated against the C 1 s peak (284.8 eV) to evaluate surface elemental composition and chemical states. N₂ adsorption-desorption (BET) of M-CN samples were measured on a fully automatic specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size distribution (Tristar II 3020 M). Raman spectra of the catalysts were acquired using a Horiba LabRAM HR Evolution spectrometer (Horiba Scientific, France) equipped with a 532 nm laser as the excitation source. The measurements were performed in the wavenumber range of 500–3500 cm-1. The d-band (∼1350 cm⁻¹) and G-band (∼1580 cm⁻¹) intensities were extracted using peak fitting software (OriginPro 2021), and the intensity ratio ID/IG was calculated to quantify the structural defects in the carbon matrix. Results and discussion The catalytic performance of the as-prepared catalysts was initially evaluated for the oxidation of HMF under optimized conditions using acetonitrile as the solvent and t-BuOOH as the oxidant. As illustrated in Fig. 1 , Fe-NC, Co-NC, Ni-NC, Mn-NC, and CoMn-NC exhibited distinct catalytic behaviors. All catalysts achieved near-complete HMF conversion (>99 %). However, significant differences in product selectivity were observed. For Fe-NC, the reaction yielded a mixture of DFF (∼13 %), FFCA (∼38 %), and FDCA (∼31 %). Ni-NC produced a ternary mixture of DFF (∼9 %), FFCA (∼37 %), and FDCA (∼47 %). In contrast, Co-NC predominantly generated FFCA (∼30 %) and FDCA (∼59 %), with negligible DFF detected. Similarly, Mn-NC favored the formation of FDCA (∼67 %) and FFCA (∼28 %), bypassing DFF accumulation. Additionally, a blank experiment was also conducted as a control. Without catalyst addition, ∼23 % HMF conversion was observed, yielding ∼2 % DFF, ∼11 % FFCA, and ∼7 % FDCA. These results highlight the critical role of the catalyst in the overall oxidation process. Evidently, based on the experimental results presented above, the catalyst samples demonstrated higher oxidation efficiency toward hydroxyl functional groups compared to aldehyde functional groups during the HMF oxidation process. Furthermore, these findings confirmed that Co-NC and Mn-NC catalysts exhibited enhanced activity in accelerating the conversion of DFF intermediates into FFCA and FDCA products. This observation corresponded with previous mechanistic studies emphasizing the synergistic redox interactions between Co and M. species during catalytic cycles [40]. To leverage this synergy, a bimetallic CoMn-NC catalyst was synthesized. Remarkably, CoMn-NC achieved complete HMF conversion with exceptional FDCA selectivity (∼95 %), demonstrating accelerated oxidation kinetics for both DFF and FFCA intermediates. Additionally, hot filtration experiments were conducted to verify the heterogeneous nature of the catalytic reaction, and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) was employed to detect metal content in the filtrate. At the reaction temperature of 80 °C, the catalyst (e.g., CoMn-NC) was mixed with the t-BuOOH/HMF system. After 1 hour of reaction, the mixture was rapidly filtered through a preheated 0.22 μm polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) membrane to separate the catalyst from the reaction solution. At this point, HMF conversion reached approximately 78 %, yielding ∼20 % DFF, ∼44 % FFCA, and ∼14 % FDCA. The filtrate was further reacted under identical conditions for up to 12 h. HPLC analysis revealed that HMF conversion exceeded 95 %, but product yields (15 % DFF, 60 % FFCA, and 22 % FDCA) were significantly lower than those obtained under standard reaction conditions. These results suggested that t-BuOOH alone could oxidize HMF, prompting supplementary control experiments. Under standard reaction conditions without catalyst addition (Fig. 1), ∼23 % HMF conversion was observed, generating ∼2 % DFF, ∼11 % FFCA, and ∼7 % FDCA, corroborating this hypothesis. Additionally, ICP-MS analysis of the filtrate detected no measurable metal ions, confirming that reaction activity primarily originated from the heterogeneous catalyst and demonstrating the stability of CoMn-NC with negligible metal leaching during the process. The divergent catalytic activities observed among the synthesized catalysts (Fe-NC, Co-NC, Ni-NC, Mn-NC, and CoMn-NC) might be primarily attributed to variations in their intrinsic physicochemical properties, including the electronic configuration of metal centers, metal loading efficiency, oxidation states, and nanostructural heterogeneity. To systematically elucidate these structure-activity relationships, a comprehensive suite of characterization techniques was employed. The crystallographic features of the catalysts were investigated by X-ray diffraction (XRD). As illustrated in Fig. 2 a, all samples exhibited a prominent diffraction peak at 26.5°, corresponding to the (002) crystallographic plane of graphitic carbon, indicative of a multilayered carbon matrix. Notably, the absence of discernible diffraction peaks associated with metallic phases or metal oxides across all five catalysts suggests the atomic-level dispersion of metal species within the carbonaceous framework. This high dispersion state was usually critical for maximizing accessible active sites in heterogeneous catalysis [39]. The lack of crystalline metal-related phases further implied that metal atoms were likely coordinated to nitrogen ligands, forming stable active centers resistant to aggregation during synthesis. Unlike bulk metal oxides, atomically dispersed metal centers minimize site-blocking effects, potentially improving catalytic efficiency in biomass conversion reactions. Subsequently, the ID/IG values of five catalysts via Raman spectroscopy were systematically analyzed, and the results demonstrated that different metal dopants significantly regulated the defect density of the carbon matrix. All samples exhibited typical d-band (∼1350 cm⁻¹) and G-band (∼1580 cm⁻¹), which corresponded to the disordered structural defects and graphitized structural features of carbon materials, respectively. The defective structures of carbon materials could expose more active sites, enhance charge transfer efficiency, and regulate metal–support interactions [41]. Specifically, Mn single-doping (Mn-NC) exhibits the highest defect density (ID/IG = 2.88), while Co-Mn bimetallic doping (CoMn-NC) balances defect generation and structural stability through a synergistic effect (ID/IG = 2.81). These data align with the mechanism of carbon etching induced by metal doping reported in the literature [42] and further validate the critical role of defect engineering in optimizing catalytic activity. Therefore, the high ID/IG ratios of Co-NC, Mn-NC, and CoMn-NC in this study provide a structural basis for their excellent catalytic performance. The textural properties of the catalysts, including specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size, were systematically investigated via N₂ adsorption-desorption isotherms. As depicted in Fig. 3 and Table 1 , Fe-NC, Co-NC, and Ni-NC exhibited comparable specific surface areas (455.8–522.4 m²/g), while Mn-NC demonstrated a significantly larger surface area (858.3 m²/g). This observation suggests that Mn incorporation enhances the development of porous structures. Consistent with this hypothesis, the bimetallic CoMn-NC displayed an increased surface area (585.4 m²/g) compared to Co-NC. Elemental analysis revealed distinct metal-loading patterns: Fe-NC, Co-NC, and Ni-NC contained approximately 2 wt % metal content, whereas Mn-NC showed reduced incorporation (1 wt %). Notably, the CoMn-NC composite achieved higher total metal loading with 2.3 wt % Co and 0.6 wt % Mn, demonstrating favorable metal co-doping efficiency. The superior catalytic performance of CoMn-NC could therefore be attributed to the optimized combination of enhanced surface area and increased active metal content. The chemical states and coordination environments of CoMn-NC were probed by FT-IR spectra (Figure S1) and XPS spectra (Fig. 4 and Table S1) [39]. As illustrated in Fig. 4b, the C 1 s spectrum deconvoluted into three primary components: graphitic CC (284.5 eV), CN (285.3 eV), and a minor oxidized CO contribution (286.8 eV) [43], the latter likely arising from ambient exposure. The dominance of CN bonding underscored the successful integration of nitrogen into the carbon matrix, a critical feature for stabilizing metal centers and modulating electronic conductivity in catalytic processes. The N 1 s spectrum (Fig. 4d) resolves five distinct nitrogen species: pyridinic N (398.5 eV), metal-coordinated N (Co/Mn-N, 399.6 eV), pyrrolic N (400.2 eV), graphitic N (401.4 eV), and π-π* satellite peaks (405.8 eV) [44]. Comparative analysis of N 1 s spectra across different catalysts (Fig. 4i-l, and Figures S2–5) confirmed consistent N speciation but distinct distribution ratios, implying metal-dependent modulation of carbon-nitrogen frameworks during synthesis. The Co 2p3/2 and Mn 2p3/2 core-level spectra (Fig. 4f-g) confirmed the absence of metallic Co (778.1 eV) or Mn (638.9 eV) phases [45], with binding energies centered at 780.7 eV and 641.2 eV, respectively. These observations, coupled with the lack of metal nanoparticles in TEM (Fig. 5 ), strongly supported the high dispersion of Co and Mn within the N-doped carbon lattice. Intriguingly, the Co binding energy in CoMn-NC exhibited a positive shift compared to Co-NC, while Mn in CoMn-NC showed a negative shift relative to Mn-NC. This reciprocal electronic perturbation implied charge redistribution between Co and Mn centers via bridging nitrogen ligands-a phenomenon consistent with bimetallic synergistic effects observed in CoFe-N-C systems for oxygen reduction [46]. The microstructural characteristics of the CoMn-NC sample were investigated via SEM and TEM. As illustrated in Fig. 1a, the CoMn-NC sample exhibited a hierarchically porous architecture with pore sizes ranging 100–200 nm, devoid of observable metal aggregates. Furthermore, TEM analysis provided additional insights into the morphology of the CoMn-NC sample (Fig. 5), revealing a predominantly uniform layered porous structure, with no evident presence of metallic nanoparticles under the high-resolution image. This observation further substantiated the high dispersion of Co and Mn elements across the catalyst surface, rather than their existence in the form of nano-clusters. Concurrently, HAADF-STEM image, BF-STEM image and EDX-mapping images (Fig. 5c-h) confirmed homogeneous distribution of C, N, Co, and Mn throughout the catalyst matrix, further supporting the absence of metal aggregation. As illustrated in Fig. 1, the CoMn-NC sample exhibited superior catalytic activity, making it the subject of subsequent investigations. The catalytic oxidation of HMF to FDCA over CoMn-NC was systematically investigated under varying reaction temperatures from room temperature to 100 °C. As illustrated in Fig. 6 a and Table S2, a pronounced temperature dependence was observed in both HMF conversion and product distribution. At room temperature, HMF conversion reached 54 %, yielding about 30 % DFF, 11 % FFCA, and 10 % FDCA (51 % carbon yield). Elevating the temperature to 40 °C significantly enhanced HMF conversion (>99 %), with FFCA (37 %) and FDCA (53 %) dominating the product profile, while DFF selectivity dropped to 8 %. And the carbon yield was about 98 %. Further increasing the temperature to 60 °C nearly eliminated DFF formation, shifting selectivity toward FDCA (71 %) with residual FFCA (25 %). Optimal performance was achieved at 80 °C, where FDCA selectivity reached 95 % with complete HMF conversion. Remarkably, at 100 °C, FDCA selectivity further improved to 97 %, demonstrating the thermal stability of the CoMn-NC catalyst under harsh conditions. At lower temperatures (40–80 °C), the reaction kinetics favored intermediate formation (DFF and FFCA), reflecting energy barriers associated with sequential oxidation steps. In contrast, elevated temperatures provided sufficient activation energy to overcome these barriers, driving the reaction toward the thermodynamically stable FDCA. The retention of high FDCA selectivity at 100 °C underscored the robustness of CoMn-NC, likely attributable to strong metal-nitrogen coordination and the hierarchical porous structure, which mitigated metal leaching or aggregation. The effect of the solvent in modulating product distribution was explored using H₂O, MeOH, EtOAc, AcOH, and MeCN (as shown in Fig. 6b, and carbon yields shown in Table S3). When using H₂O, MeOH, or AcOH as the reaction solvent, high HMF conversion (>90 %) was achieved, and FDCA selectivity varied drastically. Low FDCA yields (<30 %) accompanied by unidentified byproducts, likely due to competitive hydration of intermediates or acid-catalyzed side reactions. When H₂O or AcOH was used as the solvent, the formation of levulinic acid was detected in the reaction solution. In contrast, furyl carboxylate esters were observed in the reaction mixture when MeOH served as the solvent. Notably, no humins were detected in any of the reactions described above. When using MeCN or EtOAc as the reaction solvent, superior FDCA selectivity (89–95 %) was achieved with MeCN outperforming EtOAc slightly. The superior performance of MeCN might stem from its ability to facilitate electron transfer at the catalyst surface. Notably, the absence of proton donors in aprotic solvents suppresses the formation of gem‑diol intermediates, which were prone to over-oxidation or polymerization in protic media. These findings underscored the importance of solvent engineering in tandem with catalyst design for selective biomass valorization. The necessity of t-BuOOH as an oxidant was confirmed by control experiments: Without t-BuOOH, HMF remained unreacted (Fig. 6c). Theoretical stoichiometry predicted a 3:1 t-BuOOH:HMF ratio for complete FDCA formation. However, empirical testing revealed that 3 equivalents of t-BuOOH yielded only 80 % HMF conversion, primarily to DFF (27 %) and FFCA (42 %), with minimal FDCA (<5 %). Increasing t-BuOOH to 5 equivalents improved FDCA selectivity to 23 %, while 10 equivalents achieved quantitative HMF conversion with 95 % FDCA yield. Excess oxidant (20 equivalents) provided no further benefit, indicating saturation of active oxygen species. The multi-step nature of HMF oxidation necessitated stoichiometric excess of t-BuOOH to sustain sequential oxygen insertion. Initial steps (HMF → DFF → FFCA) required one equivalent of t-BuOOH each, and the final oxidation (FFCA → FDCA) also demanded one equivalent due to the aldehyde functionalization. Comprehensive temporal profiling of reactant conversion and product distribution was indispensable for unraveling reaction kinetics, identifying intermediates, and validating mechanistic hypotheses. In this study, we systematically tracked the oxidation of HMF to FDCA using CoMn-NC as the catalyst, with parallel experiments initiated from HMF, DFF, and FFCA under identical conditions. As shown in Fig. 7 a, HMF underwent rapid dehydrogenation, achieving 78 % conversion within 1 h, followed by gradual saturation (>95 % at 2 h, ∼100 % at 12 h). DFF selectivity peaked at 20 % within the first hour before declining, consistent with its role as a transient intermediate. Concurrently, FFCA accumulated to 53 % at 2 h, then diminished as FDCA became dominant (≥95 % at 12 h). This sequential profile (HMF → DFF → FFCA → FDCA) aligns with prior reports of hydroxymethyl-first oxidation pathways [32]. Initiation with DFF (Fig. 7b) revealed rapid consumption (75 % conversion at 1 h), accompanied by FFCA accumulation (peak at 65 %), which subsequently decreased as FDCA formed. By 8 h, DFF was fully depleted, and FDCA selectivity reached 92 %, confirming DFF→FFCA→FDCA as the dominant pathway. The kinetic lag in FDCA formation (∼3 h induction period) suggests rate-limiting steps in the final carboxylation of FFCA, likely due to steric hindrance or electronic effects at the catalyst surface. When FFCA was used as the substrate (Fig. 7c), FDCA production mirrored FFCA depletion, achieving near-quantitative conversion (>98 %) within 12 h. This direct correlation underscores FFCA as the immediate precursor to FDCA, with no detectable side products, highlighting the catalyst’s selectivity for aldehyde-to-carboxyl oxidation. The oxidation of HMF to form FDCA was generally proposed to occur through two competing pathways as shown in Scheme 1 . In Pathway I, the process involved the sequential oxidation of the hydroxymethyl group (-CH₂OH → -CHO) to produce DFF, which was then subjected to dual aldehyde oxidation (DFF → FFCA → FDCA). In Pathway II, the initial step was the oxidation of the aldehyde group (-CHO → -COOH), resulting in the formation of HMFCA, which was subsequently oxidized to FFCA and FDCA. Pathway II dominated in basic aqueous media (e.g., NaOH system) due to enhanced aldehyde hydration [29]. While the absence of HMFCA in all temporal profiles, coupled with the transient accumulation of DFF and FFCA, unambiguously established Pathway I as the operative route in this system. This preference might be attributed to the catalytic site specificity. Co/Mn=O species would exhibit stronger affinity for the hydroxymethyl group [47]. By integrating time-resolved kinetic profiling with mechanistic discrimination, this study conclusively established Pathway I as the dominant route for HMF oxidation over CoMn-NC. The catalyst’s unique ability to stabilize DFF and FFCA intermediates while avoiding HMFCA formation provided a blueprint for designing selective oxidation systems. The recyclability and structural robustness of the CoMn-NC catalyst were rigorously evaluated through five consecutive oxidation cycles of HMF to FDCA. As depicted in Fig. 8 a, the catalyst maintained exceptional performance, with HMF conversion >99 % and FDCA selectivity >90 % across all cycles. The above experimental results compellingly demonstrated that the CoMn-NC catalytic system could still maintain excellent catalytic performance after being used multiple times, without showing obvious signs of deactivation. On this basis, the used CoMn-NC was further recycled, and its elemental valence states and microscopic morphologies were analyzed through XPS and TEM characterization. XPS analysis (Fig. 8b-c, Figures S6 and Table S1) identified a positive shift in Co 2p3/2 binding energy, indicative of Co2+ oxidation to Co3+—a transition associated with the formation of reactive Co3+=O intermediates critical for -CH₂OH group or -CHO group activation. The spectral profile of Mn also exhibits a minor shift, suggesting the potential for interconversion between Mn2+ and Mn³+ oxidation states, which facilitated electron transfer during -CH2OH group or -CHO group oxidation. Notably, our experimental results confirmed that Co-NC, Mn-NC, and CoMn-NC all demonstrated effective catalytic activity for the oxidative conversion of HMF to DFF, FFCA, and FDCA. Among these catalysts, CoMn-NC exhibited superior catalytic performance, which we attributed to the synergistic interaction between Co and M. species. This conclusion was supported not only by the aforementioned XPS and Raman spectroscopic analyses but also by O2-TPD characterization of the three catalysts. As shown in Figure S7, O2-TPD profiles of Co-NC, Mn-NC, and CoMn-NC displayed distinct desorption peak temperatures. Co-NC exhibited the highest desorption temperature (∼120 °C), while Mn-NC and CoMn-NC showed similar desorption temperatures (∼110 °C). Generally, a higher desorption temperature indicated stronger binding between oxygen species and the catalyst surface. The strongest oxygen binding on Co-NC might be attributed to the electronic structure and coordination environment of Co atoms, which facilitated chemisorption of oxygen molecules. Notably, the lower desorption temperature of bimetallic CoMn-NC compared to both single-metal catalysts further confirmed the synergistic effect between Co and Mn. This synergy likely arose from two mechanisms: 1) electron transfer between the two metals altered the adsorption and activation of oxygen molecules on the catalyst surface, reducing the oxygen-catalyst binding energy; and 2) structural complementarity generated new active sites with distinct oxygen adsorption/desorption behaviors compared to single-metal sites. Such synergistic effects were critical in catalysis, as more readily desorbed oxygen species could participate more efficiently in reactions, potentially enhancing both activity and selectivity. Additionally, the C 1 s and N 1 s spectra remained virtually unchanged (Figure S6), demonstrating the structural integrity of the nitrogen-doped carbon matrix and its role in stabilizing metal centers through strong Co/Mn-N-C coordination. Furthermore, the changes in the microstructures of the used catalyst and the fresh catalyst were investigated via TEM. As shown in Fig. 8d-e, the used catalyst still retained its porous microstructure, and no obvious structural collapse was observed. Notably, there was no agglomeration of metal elements in the used catalyst, and it still maintained good dispersibility. This could be mainly attributed to the strong interaction between the metal and the support. In particular, the abundant N in the support provided effective anchoring sites for the metal elements, which can effectively inhibit the agglomeration of metal atoms and ensured that the active sites remain in an atomically dispersed state throughout multiple catalytic cycles. Conclusions In conclusion, a bimetallic CoMn-NC catalyst was successfully developed for the catalytic oxidation of HMF to FDCA in this manuscript. A systematic investigation into the reaction parameters, including solvent composition, temperature, oxidant dosage, and reaction duration, revealed their distinct mechanistic roles in governing the oxidation pathway. Optimization of these conditions achieved an exceptional FDCA yield exceeding 95 %, demonstrating the catalyst's superior performance. Crucially, the hierarchical porous architecture of the CoMn-NC framework, coupled with robust Co/Mn-N-C coordination bonds, effectively mitigated metal leaching and nanoparticle aggregation during prolonged catalysis. This structural stability was corroborated by sustained >90 % FDCA selectivity over five consecutive reaction cycles, highlighting its potential for industrial scalability. Comprehensive post-reaction characterization via XPS, and TEM provided critical insights into the catalyst's stability and active-site evolution. This work established a dual-metal synergy strategy for multi-step oxidation pathways, offering insights into the design of robust catalysts for biomass-derived platform molecule upgrading. coredata.dc:description: The development of efficient catalysts for the stepwise oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to 2,5-diformyl furan (DFF), 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA), 5-Formyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (FFCA) or 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) is critical for biomass valorization. Herein, we reported a bimetallic Co-Mn catalyst anchored on nitrogen-doped porous carbon, which was used for the oxidation of HMF to FDCA, avoiding the use of high temperature and high-pressure oxygen. High FDCA selectivity (>95 %) was achieved through reaction condition optimization. And HMF→DFF→FFCA→FDCA was considered to be the main reaction pathway during the whole oxidation process. Additionally, the chemical environment of the constituent elements of the used catalyst was analyzed by XPS. TEM revealed that the catalyst retained its porous structure and excellent metal dispersion after the reaction. This structural stability was corroborated by sustained >90 % FDCA selectivity over five consecutive reaction cycles. This work established a dual-metal synergy strategy for multi-step oxidation pathways, offering insights into the design of robust catalysts for biomass-derived platform molecule upgrading.
